body_text.text: The outbreak of 2019 novel coronavirus (COVID-19) has ben declared a pandemic spread by the World Health Organization on March 11 2020. Some countries have been hit earlier and with lightning violence, leading to the collapse of health facilities and putting public health to the test.

The epidemiological and social emergency puts at risk of under-treatment not only patients with acute infections, but also health care pathways for other diseases. Diagnostic tests and hospital facilities are largely utilized for COVID-19 patients and most of resources are invested in this field.
However, it is our duty, as surgical specialists, not to forget our patients, especially cancer patients.

What it is happening to the lung cancer pathways of referral and treatment? For how long do we have to face this emergency? What will be the cost in terms of lung cancer-related death in this scenario?
It is a management and ethics dilemma and the answer is not easy to find in absence of evidences

BIBREF0.title: A War on Two Fronts: Cancer Care in the Time of COVID-19

FIGREF0.text: in our Lung Cancer Unit a new risk stratification for lung cancer progression and COVID infection (Tab.1). We match both and elaborated a new integrated stratification risk in order to prevent adverse outcomes from COVID-19 after oncologic treatment (tab.Low risk of progression and low risk of COVID-19 infection STAGE IIa High risk of progression and low risk of COVID-19 infection STAGE IIb Low risk of progression and high risk of COVID-19 infection STAGE III High risk of progression and high risk of COVID Infection Tab.2 new integrated Risk classification We promote new therapeutic options based on the integrated classification as follow: Stage I: SURGERY. The early stages allow definitive oncological treatment without the need for further hospital admission or for adjuvant treatments. (low risk of infection) Stage IIa: SURGERY (low risk of infection) Stage IIb: Discuss with the patient also the possibility of a follow-up (up to 3 months) before a definitive therapeutic decision, once the epidemiological peak has been overcome. Personalized treatments are examined. Stage III: consider exclusive non-surgical treatments This algorithm of care tries to balance the risk of dying from cancer with the risk of incurring in a potentially fatal infection after major surgery or any onclological treatment. It is partially evidencebased and mostly based on common sense and on the need of supporting the current emergency without forgetting our patients.
